name: Avoid creating cookie without setting httpOnly option (TypeScript)
description: This rule checks that the HttpOnly option is set when an express-session is used.
output:
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided:
- The number of violation occurrences
- Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
rationale:
If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

Cross-site scripting attacks often access cookies in an attempt to steal session identifiers or authentication tokens. This is why all major browsers support the HttpOnly cookie property that prevents client-side scripts from accessing the cookie. When HttpOnly is not enabled, attackers may more easily access user cookies.
remediation: Always setting httpOnly option when creating a cookie
total: Number of TypeScript source codes using express-session
alternativeName: Always enable HttpOnly option when creating cookies so that sensitive information is not exposed to unsecured applications and domains
